Perhaps there could be a new property for certain block types (Packed Ice comes to mind): blocks placed on it can be shoved by punching them (or using a piston to shove them). Using a tool on the block would break it as normal.

Then any block could be made into a gaming piece. Although this would work really well in conjunction with the Gargoyles idea

you could use different types of wood for pieces. maybe dark oak for black and birch for white. you craft each piece individually on a crafting table, then the board. then you place the board on a block and open the chessboard. you could place the pieces on the board, or in a storage spot in the chessboard(maybe an enchantment for that.) the game could start when all the pieces are in the correct spots on the board. after each round it could lose durability. you could get exp for winning. to play an A.I. you could ask a villager to play chess. if it wants to it will go to the nearest chess board.

I dunno‚Ä¶ I find maxed impaling - in fact impaling over 4 - to be quite good.  There are some very simple ways of getting a shedload of tridents to work with so I'm not really 'feeling' what you're saying here.  You might want to think of how you adapt a grinder for instance (see my book on amazon library - search 'noob 1884')
Milk Potions shouldn't just remove potion effects, otherwise they'd be just like Milk Buckets. They should give you an extended effect that continuously blocks you from getting potion effects
While Splash Milk Potions could just instantaneously remove potion effects, stronger levels could continuously remove effects
Milk shouldn't just be put in a bottle, it should be a potion ingredient itself. When used in a brewing stand it would leave an empty bucket

A special type of milk potion could store potion effects, but only for the amount of time that was left. Redstone dust could layer be applied to increase the effect. This would be useful for storing previously unobtainable potions such as Bad Omen

While thinking about this, I realized that this is really OP considering that you really only need milk and basic brewing ingredients to be immune to potion effects. Milk should definitely be an ingredient, but there should be another ingredient and/or step that is much more difficult to achieve to balance it out

I really love this idea, and the names and effects are well thought out. I think all rings should have little backstories for the description instead of saying what it does, like I'm doing. If I were to more some rings, I'd add:

  • Beheading Ring

           Fit for a king with the power of ten charged creepers. You have a 10% chance of getting the head of the player you killed.

I think the Beheading Ring would go great with the Rename Me Ring, the ultimate disguise.

  • Experience Ring

           A ring forged by experienced warriors. You get twice as much XP from mobs and players you kill.

  • Shiny Ring

           Specially made for those who are blind. Gives all players around you (including you) the effect glowing.

WHAT?
Rings, a new item to equip, with new effects. Not craftable, great addition for the survival gameplay.

WHY?
Laking of Endgame survival experience. Going to find something very rare would be a great addition to the game. Getting 1 ring won't be very rare, but getting the ring you are researching could be really difficult.

HOW?
Just adding 1 or 2 inventory slot, on the right of the slot for the Shield.
(depending if the player can equip 1 or 2 rings)

I somehow think that being able to equip only 1 ring could be better. :P

@Zackeroni9 : rings should NOT have little backstories; Minecraft have NO little stories, just name of effects, and name of potions/items. Maybe Mojang could let a way to users an easy way to add such backstories with a datapack or so...

Sounds very useful and great idea, and not too OP as well, I really like it. But I think it could be done more believably if it was done via enchanting rather than by using different ores. In reality a gold bucket would melt much faster than an Iron bucket when holding lava and making them from different materials wouldn't increase their internal volume. But by having the ability to enchant buckets you could have more ways to balance the game regarding the use of buckets. For example enchantments could include:

unmelting (which would mean you actually need this enchantment before you can carry any lava)

unbreaking (this is needed to get your bucket back after being used to fuel a furnace with lava)

capacity 1,2,3 and 4 (which increases the buckets capacity to 8,16,32 and 64 respectively)

bottomless (a rare enchantment only granted after combining many capacity 4 buckets but which gives you infinite source blocks. Gather one lava and you'll have infinite lava blocks (when combined with unmelting). Gather 1 water and you'll have infinite water source blocks. Gather 1 fish in a bucket and you'll have infinite fish to fill your aquarium. You'll also have the ability to empty large parts of the nether of lava by being able to gather infinite lava source blocks (when combined with unmelting) Note that lava obtained from/within this bucket would probably need a different ID so that it cannot be used to power a furnace, either by placing the bucket in a furnace or filling other buckets, but otherwise would be identical. Or perhaps maybe we should be able to fuel a furnace with it?

Hey Allan Porter! I LOVE using enchantments instead of different ores, how could I have skipped past that! Allow me to streamline your idea.
So, instead of unmelting we could just use fire resistance on buckets as well as armor.
I love capacity but it seems a bit too op so we will just lower those maximum source block numbers and that‚Äôs all good. And bottomless? I think that is just SO cool, but instead of that weird combining thing you mentioned it could just be found in buried treasure (although very rarely)
ALSO the fire resistance needed to pick up lava would be great because it could prevent players from getting that cheaty diamondless nether portal.

Ah yes, fire resistance, I forgot about that lol, good call. Yes I'd be very happy with your stream lined approach. Maybe half the capacities to 4, 8, 16 and 32? Having 32 would be similar to having 36 buckets in an inventory full of buckets. Or do you think it should be less than that? Of course what I really want is a bottomless bucket haha but I agree it would have to be hard to get. It's not really OP, you can get infinite water in the ocean an infinite lave from caves/the nether. It's just a massive time saver. I like the idea of finding it in buried treasure. It would be like finding some magical lost artifact that once belonged to the one that built the nether, but it now belongs to you! So much story possibilities from just a bucket lol!

Hi, can you explain what you're looking for this to do? Not everyone is familiar with every mod and if you're looking for specific features that will help this discussion. Thanks.

I upvoted this but as an alternative, just repairing an item (without adding enchantments) should not increase the work penalty for anything. The original point of the work penalty was to make it so you can't use the same powerful weapons/armor forever, but the mending enchantment entirely nullifies this anyway. This change would make mending less of a requirement while still limiting the combination of powerful enchantments

Clarified subject to help search results.

The right fix to a right problem!

I've seen this complaint throughout the community and i think that this is a good fix. When many players are on a server, sleep barely happens meaning phantoms are a big problem when it gets later on into their spawning patterns in big groups. Many players say they are more annoying than dangerous in this situation so creating a sleep potion is a balanced way of fixing this but I think there is an even better solution.

Rather than removing or tweaking the way phantoms spawn a potion that resets the time until they come could be useful although a potion just for this problem doesn't fit into the generic themes of the other potions and seems a bit overkill for a problem like this. I think it would be better to implement a pause on the phantom timer with night vision potions. This would give night vision potions a boost of use as they don't seem to be used that much. Using night vision potions also would be easier to fit into the lore of the creatures as they are a phantom which feeds off of insomnia which night vision potions have a lot in common with.
I think that Sleep Potions should either reset the Insomnia Timer or allow the player to sleep anywhere as long as they have the potion effect. The former may fit better into Minecraft

If insomnia gives you tiredness (such as being slower or weaker), there could be potions that reset a players insomnia but not their tiredness and then other potions that revitalize players but don't reset their insomnia

These may not be potions but rather event causing effects like Bad Omen. There could also be effects for Nightmares and Dreams, the former making it so you can only lay in bed, the latter giving increased sleep benefits

It would be interesting if there were potions that could put players to sleep, making it so you can force others who refuse to. Because this may be too OP, it may just make the game see the player as asleep even though they can still move. They may have slowness and weakness as if they are tired until the effect wears off or when everyone goes to sleep and wakes up
Phantom membrane already makes a slow falling potion. We need a different ingredient
I think if your wearing the full set, you should get increased speed and jump.

Yeah, you should get increased speed and jump - and you can wall-jump, and when you crouch and touch the ceiling, you stick to the ceiling! The crafting, though? I think that the mask should require black dye, along with the rest of the set.
